arch:property.oc:show_val: We changed locus from L.1004 to L.1007 when L.1004 was at the same level as the top of wall L1008. L1007 is the occupational debris east of wall 1008, and above surface L1014. We quickly found the layer of potsmash and debris along the foundation, this layer was followed, and we discovered that it covered half of the trench. This became the bottom of L.1007 and the top of L.1014 and L.1021 It is cut by 2 pits L. 1010 and L.1012. The elevations are not to be trusted.
compact w/ very hard spots, LOTS of pottery and cobbles
This layer was darker and looser than previous layers/loci.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area B / Trench 1 / Locus 1007 (Locus)
